top_comment.text:
I totally disagree with Rand Paul probably 98 percent of the time, but he 
is spot on with this filibuster. He's actually protecting the constitution 
that American citizens shouldn't be killed by a drone (or whatever) on 
American soil without a trial. AG Eric Holder and President Obama believes 
otherwise. 

President Obama is a completely different person from 2007. He either lied 
to us for the majority of things he "stood for," or he's totally changed. I 
happen to believe the former.

Remember, Obama was supposedly against warrant-less wiretapping and the 
support of indefinite detentions for U.S. and non-citizens by the military. 
Well, that never changed. 

If you don't agree with this Rand Paul position, then you're clearly not a 
true liberal or progressive. You're not principled. ﻿
top_comment.author: Charles West

comments.text:
Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, suggested a hypothetical situation 
in which a terrorism suspect was not presenting an immediate threat — like 
“sitting in a cafe” rather than “pointing a bazooka at the Pentagon” — and 
asked whether it would be unconstitutional for the military to simply kill 
that citizen.
Mr. Holder repeatedly said that it would not be appropriate to use lethal 
force rather than arresting the suspect, but Mr. Cruz said he was asking a 
“simple question” about its constitutionality, not its propriety. Finally, 
Mr. Holder said: “Translate my ‘appropriate’ to ‘no.’ I thought I was 
saying ‘no.’ All right? ‘No.’ ”
http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/07/us/politics/senators-press-holder-on-use-of-military-force-on-us-soil.html?hp&_r=1&
comments.author: Mark Bunbury Jr.

comments.text:
+Donal von Griffyn I disagree wholeheartedly. This needs to be nipped in 
the bud, not when it is "acceptable" and a well established process. 

It will be too late by then.
comments.author: Anthony Loera

comments.text:
I had this comment in response to this discussion earlier today, and it 
applies here:
Has there been some allegation concerning an attempted drone strike on US 
soil?  Absolutely not.  So the basis for asserting that Obama needs to come 
out and say anything is somewhat tenuous.  And Attorney General Eric Holder 
did in fact state that it would require an "extraordinary circumstance" for 
such an option to be considered and that they could not rule it out should 
such "extraordinary circumstances" present themselves; however he also made 
clear that "The United State government has not carried out drone strikes 
in the United States and has no intention of doing so."  Attorney General 
Holder's letter (if you care to read it it's below and makes Rand Paul's 
entire grandstand look even more foolish than it already does) makes clear 
that it would require an extraordinary situation, like 9/11 or the attack 
on Pearl Harbor, for the President to use lethal force against an American 
citizen on American soil without using the criminal justice system which, 
AG Holder also points out, has been successfully used hundreds of times to 
convict and prosecute terrorist criminals.
http://paul.senate.gov/files/documents/BrennanHolderResponse.pdf
In sum, the entire filibuster was typical partisan nonsense and a waste of 
the American taxpayer's dollars.  If Rand Paul wants to help protect 
Americans, he should, to borrow the phrase of his fellow party member 
Speaker Boehner, "get off his ass" and get to work helping to come up with 
reasonable, bi-partisan solutions for the unemployment problem and not 
make up issues which are delusional at best.
comments.author: Mark Bunbury Jr.

comments.text:
I agree that it is wrong, but it is so very much the least of our problems 
right now and this filibuster only distracts us from the really important 
things. Like passing any one of several jobs bills which have been 
presented to Congress. I'd rather have a small chance of being murdered by 
the government with a low chance of starving than no chance of being 
murdered and a high chance of starving.
comments.author: Donal von Griffyn

comments.text:
Because the older President and Chaney did wrong, doesn't mean we should 
not kick that bucket back to the way it was, and overturn those bad calls.
comments.author: Anthony Loera

comments.text:
Have americans forgotten about extraordinary circumstances in face of 
threat as a legal basis? That was what Cheney pushed so hard to be included 
in the Patriot Act.  Obama's doing nothing worse than the president before 
him.
comments.author: Donal von Griffyn

comments.text:
+Donal von Griffyn the Holder letter says otherwise (
http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-holder-drones-20130307,0,7644844.story
)

Again, Obama has opened the door to this...even if Obama never uses Drones 
on US Citizens, who says the next crazy President might not?
comments.author: Anthony Loera

comments.text:
I don't have an issue with drones attacking US citizens on US soil, not 
logically away.  To me, this would apply to a lot of militia groups in this 
country, Tim McVey & those seriously plotting to destroy the government. 
Using as surveillance on those groups, don't have a problem with that 
either. Home grown terrorist groups have been in this country for some 
time, waiting for an opportunity to strike & honestly, that bothers me 
greatly.  There's 2 such groups in PA & while they're under 
'police surveillance', very little is done while they continue to stockpile 
weapons, gather information on targets & gain members-some of them cops!

Morally, yes, I have a problem with drone attacking on US soil without due 
process of the law. Anyone deemed a terrorist can & will be subject to laws 
that circumvent the current laws, which makes it a lot harder to justify in 
a so called democracy. As for surveillance  we're all 
under surveillance thanks to the Patriot Act & laws passed since 9/11.

The reality of the situation is we, as citizens, have no real rights  of 
privacy once we step out the front door. And sometimes, our very homes are 
monitored without our knowledge.  The best thing would be at lobby against 
the law in place now then lobby against the laws coming up. It started with 
the Patriot Act & the laws enacted from it. Get rid of those base laws & 
the other will follow.
comments.author: Dimka Mati Braswell

comments.text:
As soon as their is another terrorist attack on this country from within, 
we will see who is really concerned About what!
comments.author: Keep it 100 (G)

comments.text:
I totally disagree with Rand Paul on this issue, and on all the other 
issues.  

Obama has said several times (most recently in a G+ Hangout) that the 
government has no right to attack american citizens within america by any 
means. Saying otherwise is a lie (like most of what Rand Paul says) and 
just shows how much baseless bullshit has been pumped into this subject in 
an effort to obfuscate the truth from the average voter. I refuse to trust 
anyone who says that they would rather america fail than their political 
opponent succeed.
comments.author: Donal von Griffyn

comments.text:
You make a point +Darryle Huffman about technology. I expect that if Drones 
allow to be used to kill US Citizens, having an armed "traffic" or 
"Security" camera may not be far behind.

That is why we need to avoid this, in the first place.
comments.author: Anthony Loera

comments.text: A camera is not a drone. It's a camera.
comments.author: Dylan Tracy

comments.text:
Most people forget we already have drones and they have been used. On the 
city traffic lights the police take pictures of people running red lights 
with camera. The difference between this drone and the one in the air is 
that the one in the air may have missile at the ready. Another are is does 
the average citizen have access to have a drone under the Second Amendment?
comments.author: Darryle Huffman

comments.text:
I certainly don't like the idea of US citizens being killed by US drones 
without a trial, but I think the discussion shouldn't be quite so black and 
white; let's be real about this... 

US citizens are killed on US soil without trial fairly regularly already. 
Any time a law enforcement officer shoots to kill, that's execution without 
trial. Where's the Congressional outrage against that? Why hasn't that been 
deemed a gross breach of our constitutional rights, worthy of theatrical 
filibusters? Because we've grown accustomed to the idea that while it 
should always be questioned and investigated, *sometimes it's justified*. 
Perhaps not everybody agrees with this, but it is the status quo in the 
country today.

The only difference here is that we're talking about law enforcement using 
a remote-controlled weapon instead of a handheld weapon. With drones in the 
picture, suddenly we have nightmares of soul-less assassin machines roaming 
our countrysides and city-scapes silently picking off undesirables. While 
nobody wants that to happen, nobody (in law enforcement or otherwise) is 
suggesting that *should* happen.

The conversation should definitely be had, that's a given. The Senator's 
outrage, though, is a little overblown in my estimation. And to insinuate 
that if you don't consider it a cold-hard fact that 'drone strikes' are 
inevitably evil then *"you're not principled"* is a naive 
oversimplification, in my opinion.
comments.author: Eric King

comments.text:
yay for the talking filibuster!  high school kids across the country are 
relieved at least SOME of what they were taught turns out to be true... 
 ;-)  THIS use of filibuster: good; Patriot Act: bad
comments.author: Ron Tupa

comments.text:
I think we do have to protect our country from threats both within and 
without. Most Americans would agree that the use of drones did save lives 
of American servicemen in foreign countries now the prospect of having them 
used on American citizens poses the question What is the difference between 
using them in other countries ( which most people approved of) and using 
them in our own ( which most don't approve of? As a Kantian would say.
comments.author: Darryle Huffman

comments.text:
I agree that drone strikes against American citizens on US soil with out a 
trial is wrong, but I could see in very rare cases where it 'might' happen. 
For example, if a group of domestic terrorists commit an act of war on US 
soil (e.g. a large concerted attack against a US military base) I don't 
think they have a right to, or should expect a trial. Again, the chance of 
this happening are HIGHLY unlikely.
comments.author: John Allison

comments.text:
I havent heard a Rand idea I like but the drone issue does bother me. The 
Pseudo-Patriot act bothered me, too. Obamas continuation of Bush detention 
policies bothers me. As far as whether Obama lied or changed his mind. That 
is easy. I think most who become president were quite naive before the job. 
Things just arent black and white. The job changes people because of the 
balancing acts. I don't have any problem with killing terrorists overseas 
with drones but if they are US Citizens, there should be a special court 
like one we use regarding warrants for wiretapping, etc.
comments.author: James Veverka

comments.text:
Again +Dylan Tracy you must have a short memory... Does Ruby Ridge or the 
Waco Siege ring any bells? 

How about the guy the LA police torched in a cabin, after he was wounded, 
and alone? 

Assassination is not justice.
comments.author: Anthony Loera

comments.text:
If you're waiting for a US citizen to be killed on US soil via drone 
strike, you're going to be waiting a while.
Beyond the fact it would be an absolute PR boondoggle, and most likely an 
impeachable offense if POTUS authorizes it, the chance for collateral 
damage is far too high. We use drones in areas like Pakistan, Yemen, and 
the Maghreb because we don't have a strong ground presence there and it's 
cost-effective.
The FBI has over 36,000 employees as of September of last year, and they 
cooperate with every state law enforcement agency.

The Paul filibuster was pure theatrics by a principled (and incredibly 
ineffective) Senator who has yet to take any considerable amount of action 
in the Senate beyond voting against everything that comes to a vote.
comments.author: Dylan Tracy

comments.text:
Look he has already killed non-combatant Americans with drones, it's only a 
matter of time before they start killing people here. And sorry Holder is a 
wrong, it's not constitutional. If I am wrong please point out where it 
says the president can murder people without a trial? And no the police 
getting into a shootout isn't the same thing. You need to face facts, Bush 
may have started the ball rolling but Obama has taken it to a whole new 
level of evil.
comments.author: Igbo Anyanwu

comments.text:
I don't agree with the policy, but I think Holder's answer is being 
misconstrued.  There is a huge difference in saying the policy is legal and 
the policy is okay.  The AG answered the question based on the legal 
question.  He cannot, in his capacity as AG speak to the moral question. 
 Again, not defending the policy AT ALL, but I think we need to be careful 
how we characterize people in this.  Focus on the legal question and 
fighting it on Constitutional grounds and keep the character assassinations 
out of it.  This policy existed prior to the Obama administration.
comments.author: Korinne M Jackman

comments.text:
If they had the principals I thought they did it wouldn't matter what Obama 
and Harry Reid said.
